findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop all users from buying excluding authorized addresses by setting the `maxWalletAmount` to zero.

findings.title: FRV - Fee Restoration Vulnerability
findings.description: The contract demonstrates a potential vulnerability upon removing and restoring the fees when the fees have been set to zero.

findings.title: MMN - Misleading Method Naming
findings.description: Methods can have misleading names if their names do not accurately reflect the functionality they contain or the purpose they serve.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `fundAddress` as part of the transfer flow. This address can either be a wallet address or a contract. If the address belongs to a contract then it may revert from incoming payment. As a result, the error will propagate to the token’s contract and revert the transfer.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract accumulates tokens from taxes to swap them for ETH. If `swapTokensAtAmount` is set to a big number, it can trigger a huge token swap, leading to significant price volatility due to the token's highly volatile price.

findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: RED - Redundant Event Declaration
findings.description: The contract declares certain events that are not used in a meaningful way by the contract.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions greater than or equal to 0.8.0 provide native functionality for arithmetic operations.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure they cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not follow the Solidity naming convention guidelines, which can affect readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract.

findings.title: L13 - Divide before Multiply Operation
findings.description: Performing divisions before multiplications may cause loss of precision.

findings.title: L14 - Uninitialized Variables in Local Scope
findings.description: Using an uninitialized local variable can lead to unpredictable behavior and potentially cause errors in the contract.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured by user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.

findings.title: L20 - Succeeded Transfer Check
findings.description: The transfer methods should be checked if the result is successful according to the ERC20 specification, otherwise, the contract may wrongly assume that the transfer has been established.
